metadata.title: The Cotton Harvester in Retrospect: Labor Displacement or Replacement?

relevance.topic: Labor displacement due to technological change in agriculture
relevance.relevance: The study examines the impact of mechanical cotton harvesters on labor displacement in agriculture, specifically testing the 'labor push' versus 'labor pull' hypotheses.

dependent_variables.displaced: 79 percent of the reduction in hand picking of cotton was due to increased nonfarm wages; 21 percent due to decreased cost of machine harvesting.

historical_context.economic_conditions: The U.S. farm labor force declined by about two-thirds from 1930 to 1980, with a tenfold increase in the machinery-labor ratio.
historical_context.institutional_context: The study discusses the role of research institutions and machinery manufacturers in responding to market forces.

outcomes.main_findings: The study finds that 79% of the reduction in hand picking of cotton was due to increased nonfarm wages (pull effect), while 21% was due to the decreased cost of machine harvesting (push effect).
outcomes.conclusions: The pull effect of higher nonfarm wages was almost four times stronger than the push effect of mechanization in reducing farm labor employment in cotton harvesting.

quality_assessment.methodological_limitations: The study relies on econometric modeling and historical data, which may have limitations in capturing all variables affecting labor displacement.
quality_assessment.coherence: The study provides a coherent analysis of the labor market for cotton pickers, using a simultaneous-equation model to test hypotheses.
quality_assessment.adequacy_of_data: The study uses a comprehensive data set from 1930 to 1964, covering 12 major cotton-producing states.
quality_assessment.relevance: The study is highly relevant to understanding labor displacement in agriculture due to technological change.
